definitions: enter a place or country forcefully as an enemy or conqueror
intrude upon or violate someone's privacy or personal space without permission
spread harmfully into an area or organism like disease or pests
examples: The army invaded the neighboring country at dawn yesterday
Viking warriors invaded Britain during the ninth century repeatedly
Reporters constantly invade celebrities' privacy for sensational stories daily
Please don't invade my personal space while I'm working
Cancer cells can invade healthy tissue and spread rapidly
Weeds quickly invaded the garden after the spring rains

definitions: make something legally void or null by declaring it invalid officially
prove that an argument or theory is incorrect or without foundation
examples: The court decided to invalidate the contract due to fraud
Missing signatures will invalidate your passport application completely today
New evidence completely invalidates the prosecution's main theory entirely
These findings invalidate previous assumptions about climate change patterns

definitions: create or design something that has never been made or existed before
make up or fabricate a story or excuse that is not true
examples: Thomas Edison invented the light bulb in the nineteenth century
Scientists are trying to invent new medicines for rare diseases
Children often invent imaginary friends during their early childhood years
He invented an elaborate excuse for missing the important meeting

definitions: make a complete and detailed list of items in a collection or property
count and assess the quantity of goods or supplies in stock systematically
examples: We need to inventory all equipment before the audit tomorrow
The museum staff will inventory the entire collection this month
Store employees inventory the merchandise every quarter for accuracy checks
The warehouse manager inventories supplies at the end of each week

definitions: turn something upside down or place it in the opposite position physically
reverse the normal order or position of elements in a sequence or structure
examples: Please invert the jar to mix the contents thoroughly together
The gymnast inverted her body during the complex floor routine
The programmer needs to invert the array for proper data processing
Musicians sometimes invert chord progressions to create interesting harmonies

definitions: commit money or capital to something in order to gain financial returns
devote time effort or energy to a particular undertaking with expectation of benefit
formally confer a rank or office upon someone with ceremony
examples: She decided to invest her savings in technology company stocks
Many people invest in real estate for long-term financial growth
Parents invest considerable time in their children's education and development
The company invests heavily in employee training and professional development
The queen will invest him with knighthood at the ceremony
The president invested the general with full military command authority

definitions: carry out a systematic examination or formal inquiry to discover facts about something
conduct an official examination into a crime or alleged wrongdoing
examples: Scientists investigate the causes of climate change through extensive research
Journalists investigate corruption scandals to expose the truth publicly
Police officers investigate crimes to identify and apprehend the perpetrators
The committee will investigate allegations of financial misconduct thoroughly tomorrow

definitions: politely request someone's presence at an event or to participate in something
attract provoke or make something unpleasant more likely to happen
examples: We decided to invite all our neighbors to the summer barbecue
The company will invite candidates for interviews next week Monday
Leaving valuables visible in your car invites theft and vandalism
Such reckless behavior invites criticism from the media and public

definitions: send a bill or written statement of charges for goods or services provided
examples: The contractor will invoice us for the completed renovation work tomorrow
We invoice our clients at the end of each month regularly

definitions: call upon someone or something for aid support or inspiration formally
cite or appeal to something as an authority or justification for action
call upon a deity or supernatural force through prayer or magic ritual
examples: The president invoked emergency powers to address the national crisis
Lawyers often invoke precedent cases to support their legal arguments
The defendant invoked the Fifth Amendment during questioning by police yesterday
The contract invokes specific clauses for breach of agreement penalties
The priestess invoked ancient gods during the sacred ceremony last night
Witches in stories often invoke spirits through mysterious incantations carefully

definitions: include someone or something as a necessary participant or part of something
have or require something as a necessary feature consequence or result
examples: The new project involves several departments working together collaboratively daily
Please don't involve me in your personal disputes with colleagues
This job involves extensive travel to different countries every month
The renovation will involve significant disruption to normal business operations

definitions: press clothes or fabric with a heated iron to remove wrinkles and creases
examples: She needs to iron her dress before the wedding ceremony tomorrow
I iron my shirts every Sunday evening for the work week

definitions: supply water to land or crops artificially through channels pipes or streams
examples: Farmers irrigate their fields during the dry summer months regularly
The new system will irrigate thousands of acres of farmland efficiently

definitions: make someone angry or annoyed by persistent unpleasant behavior or actions
cause physical discomfort inflammation or itching to skin or body parts
examples: His constant interruptions really irritate me during important meetings always
Loud music from neighbors irritates residents late at night frequently
The harsh soap irritates my sensitive skin causing redness and itching
Smoke from the fire irritates eyes and throat making breathing difficult

definitions: separate someone or something from other people or things physically or socially
identify and separate a specific element substance or factor for examination
examples: The hospital isolates infectious patients to prevent disease spread effectively
Remote location isolates the village from modern civilization completely
Scientists isolate specific genes to study their functions in detail
Researchers need to isolate variables in controlled experiments carefully always

definitions: formally distribute or provide something official like documents or statements publicly
emerge or flow out from a source or point of origin
examples: The government will issue new passports with enhanced security features soon
The company issued a statement denying all allegations yesterday morning
Smoke issued from the chimney on the cold winter morning slowly
A strange sound issued from the darkness startling everyone nearby

definitions: feel an uncomfortable sensation on the skin that causes desire to scratch
have a strong restless desire or urge to do something
examples: My mosquito bites itch terribly making it hard to sleep tonight
The wool sweater makes my skin itch uncomfortably all day long
She's itching to travel abroad after years of staying home
The team is itching for revenge after last season's defeat

definitions: perform or repeat a process or sequence of operations successively to achieve desired result
examples: Programmers iterate through arrays to process each element sequentially
The team will iterate on the design until it meets requirements

definitions: poke or thrust sharply and quickly with something pointed or with fist
examples: The nurse jabbed the needle into my arm for the vaccination
The boxer jabbed repeatedly at his opponent's defensive guard persistently

definitions: lift something heavy using a mechanical jack device for support or repair
suddenly increase prices or rates to an unreasonably high level
examples: He needs to jack up the car to change the flat tire
Workers jacked the house foundation to repair the damaged beams
The company jacked up prices before the holiday shopping season began
Landlords often jack up rent when demand exceeds available supply

definitions: cover or enclose something with a protective outer layer or casing
examples: The publisher will jacket the book with an attractive dust cover
Engineers jacket cables with insulation to prevent electrical hazards completely

definitions: cut or tear something to create an uneven jagged edge or surface
examples: The broken glass jagged the fabric creating an irregular tear pattern
Rocky cliffs jag the coastline making navigation dangerous for small boats

definitions: put someone in jail or prison as legal punishment for a crime
examples: The judge decided to jail him for three years for fraud
Authorities jailed several protesters after the violent demonstration yesterday evening

definitions: squeeze or pack things or people tightly into a confined space forcefully
block or obstruct something causing it to become stuck and unable to move
play music informally and spontaneously especially in a group session
examples: Commuters jam into subway cars during the morning rush hour daily
She jammed all her clothes into one small suitcase hurriedly
Paper scraps jammed the printer preventing it from working properly today
Traffic jams the highway every Friday evening without fail consistently
The band loves to jam together after their formal concerts end
Musicians jam at the local club every Thursday night enthusiastically

definitions: make or cause to make a harsh metallic ringing or clanging sound
examples: The keys jangle loudly in his pocket as he walks quickly
Wind chimes jangle harshly in the strong storm winds outside tonight

definitions: shake or vibrate someone or something suddenly with harsh abrupt movement
have an unpleasant jarring or conflicting effect on someone's feelings or senses
examples: The explosion jarred the entire building violently waking everyone inside immediately
The bus jarred passengers when it hit the deep pothole suddenly
His rude comments jarred with the formal atmosphere of the dinner
Bright colors jar against the subtle decor of the elegant room

definitions: talk at length in a boring gossipy or scolding manner persistently
examples: The neighbors jaw endlessly about everyone's personal business all day
Stop jawing and get back to work on the project immediately

definitions: make something more lively interesting or exciting through creative additions or modifications
examples: Let's jazz up the presentation with colorful graphics and animations
The chef jazzed up traditional recipes with exotic spices creatively

definitions: become firm like jelly or gel through cooling or chemical process
take definite form or begin to work well as ideas or plans
examples: The mixture will jell after refrigerating for three hours minimum
Pectin helps fruit preserves jell into the proper consistency quickly
Our vacation plans finally jelled after weeks of discussion and planning
The team's strategy jelled perfectly during the second half yesterday

definitions: convert or cause something to become jelly or a jelly-like substance
examples: The cook will jelly the fruit juice with pectin and sugar
Cold temperatures jelly the oil making it difficult to pour

definitions: put something valuable or important at risk of loss harm or failure
examples: Don't jeopardize your career with such reckless behavior at work
Poor decisions could jeopardize the company's future success and stability

definitions: pull push or twist something with a sudden sharp quick movement forcefully
move with sudden sharp motions or spasms often involuntarily
examples: She jerked the rope to signal the crew to stop immediately
The child jerked his hand away from the hot stove quickly
The train jerked forward suddenly throwing passengers off balance completely
His muscles jerk involuntarily due to the neurological condition unfortunately

definitions: speak or act in a joking playful or humorous manner without serious intent
examples: He often jests about serious matters to lighten the mood considerably
The comedian jests with the audience throughout the entire performance nightly

definitions: travel by jet aircraft especially over long distances quickly and luxuriously
spout out forcefully in a stream under pressure like water or gas
examples: Business executives jet around the world for important meetings regularly
Celebrities often jet to exotic locations for vacation getaways frequently
Water jets from the broken pipe flooding the basement floor rapidly
Steam jets out from the pressure valve when temperature rises high

definitions: deliberately throw cargo or equipment overboard to lighten a ship or aircraft
abandon or discard something that is no longer wanted or needed
examples: The captain ordered crew to jettison cargo during the violent storm
Pilots may jettison fuel tanks in emergency situations for safety reasons
The company decided to jettison unprofitable divisions to reduce losses significantly
Politicians often jettison controversial policies before important elections strategically

definitions: decorate or adorn something with jewels or precious stones for beautification
examples: The craftsman will jewel the crown with diamonds and rubies carefully
Ancient rulers jeweled their swords to display wealth and power prominently

definitions: dance a lively jumping dance or move with quick jerky movements energetically
examples: The children jig excitedly when their favorite song plays loudly
Irish dancers jig to traditional folk music at the festival annually

definitions: force open a door or window with a crowbar or similar tool illegally
examples: Burglars tried to jimmy the back door lock last night unsuccessfully
The thief jimmied open the window to enter the house quietly

definitions: make or cause to make a light metallic ringing or tinkling sound
examples: Coins jingle in his pocket as he walks down the street
She jingles her keys to get the baby's attention quickly

definitions: bring bad luck to someone or something through supernatural curse or influence
examples: Don't jinx the game by talking about winning before it ends
Some athletes believe certain actions jinx their performance during competitions

definitions: dance to swing or jazz music with lively energetic movements enthusiastically
talk in a deceptive exaggerated or meaningless way to mislead others
examples: Couples jive enthusiastically to big band music at the dance hall
Young people loved to jive at sock hops in the fifties
Don't jive me with your elaborate excuses for being late again
Politicians often jive voters with empty promises during campaign season

definitions: do piecework or work by individual tasks rather than regular employment
work at occasional jobs or tasks for payment without permanent employment
examples: Freelance writers job for various magazines throughout the year regularly
Contractors job on different construction sites depending on available work
Students often job during summer breaks to earn extra money quickly
He jobs as a handyman on weekends for additional income support

definitions: maneuver or manipulate skillfully to gain advantageous position or achieve something
ride horses professionally in races as a competitive sport occupation
examples: Executives jockey for position before the CEO retirement announcement comes
Drivers jockey for the best parking spots during holiday shopping season
Professional riders jockey thoroughbred horses at major racing events worldwide
She trained for years to jockey at the Kentucky Derby successfully

definitions: run at a slow regular pace as a form of physical exercise
give a slight push or nudge to stimulate memory or attention
examples: She jogs three miles every morning before breakfast for fitness
Many people jog in the park during pleasant weather conditions regularly
This photo might jog your memory about that summer vacation trip
Let me jog your elbow to get your attention right now

definitions: connect or fasten two or more things together to form a unit
become a member of an organization group or community formally
come together with others to participate in an activity or effort
examples: The plumber will join these pipes with a special adhesive tomorrow
Carpenters join wood pieces using various techniques and strong fasteners
She decided to join the chess club at school this semester
Many graduates join professional associations in their field after college
Everyone joined in singing happy birthday at the surprise party yesterday
Let's join forces to complete this project more efficiently together

definitions: fit or unite pieces together precisely at joints especially in carpentry
examples: The carpenter will joint the boards perfectly for a seamless tabletop
Skilled craftsmen joint wood pieces without visible gaps or imperfections

definitions: tell jokes or say something funny to cause amusement and laughter
speak insincerely or not seriously about something as if kidding
examples: Comedians joke about everyday situations to make audiences laugh heartily
Friends often joke around during casual gatherings and social events
Don't joke about such serious matters that affect people's lives
I was only joking when I said I'd quit my job

definitions: encourage or coax someone in a cheerful friendly manner to improve mood
examples: She tried to jolly him out of his bad mood with funny stories
The host jollied guests along ensuring everyone enjoyed the party thoroughly

definitions: shake or move with sudden rough jerky movements causing physical disruption
give someone an emotional or mental shock that disturbs severely
examples: The earthquake jolted buildings throughout the city causing widespread panic immediately
The bus jolted passengers when it hit deep potholes unexpectedly
The bad news jolted her from her comfortable complacency about life
His harsh criticism jolted me into reconsidering my entire approach completely

definitions: tease someone in a playful good-natured way without malicious intent
examples: Friends josh each other about their favorite sports teams constantly
His colleagues josh him about his unusual lunch choices every day
